title: Pros and cons of 'off-market' property transactions
text:
Keen buyers are being encouraged to make blind bids on unadvertised properties by sellers' agents making the most of a worsening shortage.

In many cases agents say demand is so high that they advocate no auction but an "off-market" deal without advertising or marketing to promote the sale. Agents have so many buyers on their lists that properties are pitched directly to them.

Agents are encouraging potential buyers to make a high offer up to 15 per cent above the reserve price to drive off competitors for off-market deals and ahead of scheduled auctions.

But there is no guarantee unconventional strategies are going to secure a higher price than a traditional auction in competitive markets driven by falling borrowing costs and rising confidence.

What is sharply tilting the market in favour of sellers are “abnormal” conditions causing supply to slip further behind demand, even in September, the first month of spring, when new listings traditionally rise, according to SQM Research, which monitors market prices.

Rapidly increasing prices during the past three months mean that underquoting could be on the rise as properties sell higher than real estate agents’ quotes, which in Victoria are typically based on local sales during the previous three months, according to Damian Taylor, a buyer’s agent for Morrell and Koren.
description: With so many properties selling on the quiet or ahead of auction, buyers and sellers need to be ahead of the game.
